text: This isn't about me personally (I'm just getting started on my own system), but this is from the experience of working for a client who did pay PC

elements.text: This isn't about me personally (I'm just getting started on my own system), but this is from the experience of working for a client who did pay PC

text: ....hard to see a scenario where this is a good idea.... Are you completely clear on how PC and implied comm work? You are only credited for 1/2 your comm and 1/2 your IC which is always 2.5%. For most people that means that if you're on 2% your total charges are slightly less than your PC rate, at 8% they'll be quite a bit more. There might be some weird scenario where a higher comm rate makes sense but for the overwhelming majority 2% is the best option and suggesting a higher rate would be very poor advice.

elements.text: ....hard to see a scenario where this is a good idea.... Are you completely clear on how PC and implied comm work? You are only credited for 1/2 your comm and 1/2 your IC which is always 2.5%. For most people that means that if you're on 2% your total charges are slightly less than your PC rate, at 8% they'll be quite a bit more. There might be some weird scenario where a higher comm rate makes sense but for the overwhelming majority 2% is the best option and suggesting a higher rate would be very poor advice.

text: Are most people in that position?

text: I my case I pay 40% and my lifetime comm generated is about 11%, however my typical comm generated is now about 5% so that figure is steadily coming down and I will likely end up at 50%. I've been through my options very carefully and it's clear that my best option is still 2%. You have to remember that your goal is not to avoid paying PC but to take home as much money as possible.

elements.text: I my case I pay 40% and my lifetime comm generated is about 11%, however my typical comm generated is now about 5% so that figure is steadily coming down and I will likely end up at 50%. I've been through my options very carefully and it's clear that my best option is still 2%. You have to remember that your goal is not to avoid paying PC but to take home as much money as possible.

text: Do you have any example calculations?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Do you have any example calculations?

text: Take the simplest possible case - you're on 20% and you win 100% of your markets. You win £100. On 2% you pay £2 in regular comm, then £19 in PC - so you pay £21 all in. On 8% you pay £8 in comm and £16 in PC - so that's £24.

elements.text: Take the simplest possible case - you're on 20% and you win 100% of your markets. You win £100. On 2% you pay £2 in regular comm, then £19 in PC - so you pay £21 all in. On 8% you pay £8 in comm and £16 in PC - so that's £24.

text: In a  more realistic example: say you win £1000 and lose £500: in that case on 2% you pay £20 in comm for which you're credited £10 towards PC and you generate IC of £12.5 - of which they credit you £6.25, so you're due for £83.75 in PC - so that's total charges paid of £103.75.

elements.text: In a  more realistic example: say you win £1000 and lose £500: in that case on 2% you pay £20 in comm for which you're credited £10 towards PC and you generate IC of £12.5 - of which they credit you £6.25, so you're due for £83.75 in PC - so that's total charges paid of £103.75.

text: On 8% you pay £80 in comm (credited for £40) and still generate £6.25 of IC, PC due is £53.75 - total charges paid is £133.75

elements.text: On 8% you pay £80 in comm (credited for £40) and still generate £6.25 of IC, PC due is £53.75 - total charges paid is £133.75

text: Mo's point is that a higher comm rate might mean that your lifetime comm generated might stay above 10% so you're limiting your PC rate to no more than 40% - but you're paying a lot for it in the meantime, and you're only being credited with half of that towards your lifetime comm generated.

elements.text: Mo's point is that a higher comm rate might mean that your lifetime comm generated might stay above 10% so you're limiting your PC rate to no more than 40% - but you're paying a lot for it in the meantime, and you're only being credited with half of that towards your lifetime comm generated.

text: Would your advice change if it was a choice of 8%/40% PC, or 2%/50%PC?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Would your advice change if it was a choice of 8%/40% PC, or 2%/50%PC?

text: Assuming the rest of the rules stayed the same 8% and 40% PC would be better - but you don't get that option.

elements.text: Assuming the rest of the rules stayed the same 8% and 40% PC would be better - but you don't get that option.

text: The question of whether you can keep yourself out of a higher PC bracket in the future is more complicated than it first appears too.

elements.text: The question of whether you can keep yourself out of a higher PC bracket in the future is more complicated than it first appears too.

text: You really need to factor in how your betting is likely to change and you should discount your projected winning for uncertainty.

elements.text: You really need to factor in how your betting is likely to change and you should discount your projected winning for uncertainty.

text: In general - most of what gets said about avoiding PC doesn't stand up and the best bet is just to pay the minimum possible in the here and now.

elements.text: In general - most of what gets said about avoiding PC doesn't stand up and the best bet is just to pay the minimum possible in the here and now.

text: The only deals I've ever been offered (or even heard of) are for specific sports that BF want to build up. Other than that some people have arrangements to pay in a different structures but it never results in paying less. Basically - if you win you pay, which is still better than the rest who lose and pay even more.

text:
Suppose we consider 5%/50% as the base case. That person would make 5% more than someone paying 8%/50%. However, if they are borderline against the 60% PC they could slip into 2%/60% or 5%/60% bands. Which would be 17% or 12% worse.

Assuming a 50% chance of falling into the 60% PC band, that person would be better off paying the 8%.

I wonder if, in such situations, the total charges/profit % could be increased just by placing mug punts with little edge?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

text: Honestly here's the best advice I can give about charges: Just forget about them. Concentrate on maximising your winnings instead, that's by far the best way to take more money home - which is the thing that really matters.

text:
But....

Suppose one thousand £2.00 bets were placed at 2.00 (assuming that is fair value).

The 2% payer would expect to win £980. Lose £1000.

Adding that to some scenarios in my spreadsheet, I can see it beating 5%/50%, while helping to keep the Total Charges% above %.

But I guess the ability to bet at 2.00 fair value isn't really possible.

text: Yeah - randomly placed bets are slightly -EV.

text: And if you were placing a tonne of 0EV bets; why wouldn't you work to make them +EV? That way you'd take home more money.

elements.text: And if you were placing a tonne of 0EV bets; why wouldn't you work to make them +EV? That way you'd take home more money.

text: BTW, I have done some simple calculations on previous results with PC. In Australia outside horse racing a punter operates with a standard rate of 5% commission, which you can halve with a discount by turning over volume. I won't go into the calculations, but all the PC does is effectively remove the discount and puts you back to the standard 5% commission. Whether this works at the margins (very high POT% or very low POT%) I'm not sure, but it is a good guide for a POT% of around 10-15
